This P/E based on fundamentals is also referred to as a justified P/E. It is “justified”
because, assuming we have the correct inputs for D, E, k., and g, the equation above
will provide a P/E ratio that is based on the present value of the future cash flows. We
refer to this as a leading P/E ratio because it is based on expected earnings next period,
not on actual earnings for the previous period, which would produce a lagging or trailing
PIE ratio.
